filmProgrammings.email_subject: Strike a Pose, Vogue
filmProgrammings.our_take: André Leon Talley, who died in January, was a force of nature: a statuesque titan of fashion, and right-hand man to Anna Wintour at American Vogue. Kate Novack’s documentary reveals the man behind the bling, charting the hard road traveled, from a segregated South to the elite echelons of couture.

Kate Novack’s documentary reveals the man behind the bling, charting the hard road traveled, from a segregated South to the elite echelons of couture.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Romance & Slapstick: Sophie Letourneur's GABY BABY DOLL
filmProgrammings.our_take: Writer-director-actor Sophie Letourneur has made a mark in French cinema as an auteur of female-led audacities. This film, a dual act starring Lolita Chammah (Isabelle Huppert’s daughter!), is both slapstick comedy and gentle romance: a hard-learned lesson in either solitude, or companionship.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Flick or Treat: Halloween Horror | NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD
filmProgrammings.our_take: Some like ghost stories, and some prefer their undead as a bloodthirsty horde. Here’s where the world’s zombie obsession began: George Romero’s landmark classic, a raging, subversive, apocalyptic bonfire of a film. By the time the lights came up, horror would never be the same—and it still shocks.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: A Perfect Summer Getaway to Marseilles
filmProgrammings.our_take: A love letter to Marseilles, Dominique Cabrera’s youthful drama glimmers with all the delights of a perfect summer vacation, from sun-kissed tans to warm seaside dips. Starring the bewitching Lola Créton (Goodbye First Love), this bittersweet gem finds the darkness that lurks beneath the sunshine.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Jacques Feyder's Unsentimental Portrait of Chilhood Blues
filmProgrammings.our_take: An unsentimental portrait of childhood blues, this tumultuous family drama from French master Jacques Feyder is remarkably modern for its time. Awe-striking in their resplendence, the mountains and rivers of Switzerland beautifully mirror the stormy emotions that swell within a motherless young boy.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: SPECTRE, SANITY, MADNESS AND THE FAMILY | A MUBI Release
filmProgrammings.our_take: Excavating an unusual family archive laden with secrets, this mesmerizing first feature from French composer Jean-Baptiste de Laubier, aka Para One, is a sonic journey through the ghosts of childhood. Echoing his collaborations with Céline Sciamma, the enigmatic score unlocks a portal to the past.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Thinking of You: Two Films by Morgan Quaintance | SURVIVING YOU, ALWAYS
filmProgrammings.our_take: While an icon of 1960s counterculture enthuses mystically about hallucinogens, Morgan Quaintance reflects on growing up high with sober disillusionment. In monochrome recollections of ’90s South London, the British artist is romantic about only one thing: in the end, love is the drug that remains.
filmProgrammings.our_take_html: While an icon of 1960s counterculture enthuses mystically about hallucinogens, Morgan Quaintance reflects on growing up high with sober disillusionment. In monochrome recollections of ’90s South London, the British artist is romantic about only one thing: in the end, love is the drug that remains.

primary_film_group.title: Thinking of You:
primary_film_group.description: It’s 3am again, and Morgan Quaintance is awake. In 1993, this was the time for watching fireworks and falling in love. Now it is the hour of insomnia, solitude, and thinking about “odd things”—like the possible saintliness of his suffering. Often set at night and in the cloudy waters of post-breakup sadness, both films in our double bill find the British artist-filmmaker immersed in introspection. In Surviving You, Always (2020) and A Human Certainty (2021), Quaintance is intermittently carried away from himself and his London surrounds by digressive streams of thought: reflecting on his family history across the Black Atlantic in one moment, then anti-psychiatry of the 1960s and photojournalism of the 1930s in the next. In the two shorts, he also beautifully captures the poor image that is memory: the people of the past are glimpsed in close-up and slow, staccato motion, with the image out of focus and further obscured by grainy, monochrome 16mm film. Quaintance supplements that uncertain image in various ways, continually combining written word, sound, music and image to create formally generous films. Writing as a critic for the magazine Art Monthly, Quaintance has recently decried the slide of British multiculturalism into a monoculture: everything looks the same, he laments, and says the same thing. Nothing could be further from the truth when it comes to these two shorts. Intensely intimate, tender and wry, his idiosyncratic films escape this contemporary condition.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Thinking of You: Two Films by Morgan Quaintance | A HUMAN CERTAINTY
filmProgrammings.our_take: In A Human Certainty, the brooding, post-breakup narrator senses an ending wherever his thoughts take him—even a beach may as well be a graveyard. Balancing wounding honesty with wry humor, Morgan Quaintance captures the inescapable torment of heartbreak, where all is haunted and everything hurts.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Alex Gibney's Searing Investigation of Corporate Malfeasance
filmProgrammings.our_take: It’s fascinating to watch Alex Gibney’s searing investigation of Enron’s corporate malfeasance in the years following the 2008 economic crash. What once looked like a historic reckoning, now feels terrifyingly prophetic. Methodical and damning, it’s one of the great documentarian’s very best films.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Christophe Honoré's Heady Tale of Love and Resilience
filmProgrammings.our_take: A film of profound resilience and fragility, Christophe Honoré’s queer romantic drama glows with the warmth of a new love that blooms underneath the specter of the AIDS crisis. Intimacy is evoked, not only with electrifying carnal touches, but also through thrilling exchanges on art and literature.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Martine Syms's THE AFRICAN DESPERATE | A MUBI Release
filmProgrammings.our_take: Chaos reigns in the riotously funny debut feature from visual artist Martine Syms. With a breakthrough performance from Diamond Stingily, this hallucinatory day-in-the-life of a Black artist is a rollicking satire of art-world pretensions and a rowdy portrayal of sex and drugs in the Internet age.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: A Sequestered Family Gone Haywire
filmProgrammings.our_take: Reminiscent of Yorgos Lanthimos’s Dogtooth, Emir Baigazin’s unsettling drama dreams up an eerily sequestered existence in a remote Kazakh village where paternal authoritarianism reigns. Under the intrusion of technology, the lush, ascetic cinematography gives way to shocking familial transgressions.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Erik Blomberg's THE WHITE REINDEER | A MUBI Release
filmProgrammings.our_take: Drawing from the deep well of beliefs of the semi-nomadic Sámi people, Erik Blomberg’s Finnish folk horror is a snow-encrusted tale of shape-shifting shamanism. Weirdness lurks deep in the desolate landscape of Lapland, where the fight to survive rubs up against the insatiable hunger for love.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: A Window into New Indian Cinema: THE GOLD-LADEN SHEEP & THE SACRED MOUNTAIN
filmProgrammings.our_take: In this mystical drama, a shepherd’s holy-mountain quest transforms into a metaphysical fable about mankind’s search for the sacred. The first film spoken in the Gaddi dialect of a nomadic Himalayan tribe, Ridham Janve’s bold debut ingeniously segues between the surreal and the documentary.

primary_film_group.title: A Window into New Indian Cinema
primary_film_group.title_upcase: A WINDOW INTO NEW INDIAN CINEMA
primary_film_group.description: Contemporary independent Indian cinema is, like the country itself, an eclectic symphony of voices. This program looks at India through the eyes of some of its boldest emerging indie filmmakers. By bringing the local to global audiences, these works foreground their directors’ nonconformist perspectives and showcase diverse stories of life at the margins of India’s towns and cities. Whether tracking the rapidly changing social or political situation of its cities and towns, or documenting its rich tapestries of folk customs, social histories and traditions, these films open a window on a country that’s always on the cusp of change. Prepare to be inspired.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Paris Belongs to Jacques Rivette!
filmProgrammings.our_take: One of the key inciting films of the French New Wave, Jacques Rivette’s rough-and-ready debut is an enigmatic time-capsule of Left Bank Paris. Centering on a no-budget theatrical production and imbued with conspiratorial anxiety, this quasi-thriller couldn’t be mistaken for the work of anyone else!

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Powell & Pressburger Together & Apart: THE TALES OF HOFFMANN
filmProgrammings.our_take: Powell & Pressburger’s resplendent Technicolor adaptation of the E.T.A. Hoffmann opera reveals, once more, the duo’s boundless cinematic imagination. Unabashedly opulent in its flamboyant colour-coded scenes, which daringly combine theatre, dance, opera and film, it’s a total feast for the senses.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Lucile Hadžihalilović's EARWIG | A MUBI Release
filmProgrammings.our_take: Strange objects, secret prisons, and uncanny stories of children growing up continue to fascinate Lucile Hadžihalilović in the eerie and mysterious Earwig. Spine-tingling in both its beauty and its creepiness, her cinema of curiosities shares a surrealist realm with Cronenberg and Lynch.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: The Passions of Pasolini: LA RICOTTA
filmProgrammings.our_take: Playing havoc with the hierarchies of both religion and filmmaking, Pier Paolo Pasolini’s riotous farce ferociously articulates his radical beliefs, for which he was charged with blasphemy. Bolstered by Orson Welles’s magnetic presence, the film ingeniously mixes zany slapstick with gutting tragedy.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Refugee Lives Told in Vivid Depth
filmProgrammings.our_take: A symbol in the media for the hostility endured by asylum seekers, Ossamah Al Mohsen continues to face bureaucratic cruelty after settling in Spain. Bringing together his new life and the fate of Syrian footballers stuck in Turkey, this tender documentary lends a human depth to faceless statistics.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Carlos Saura's ROSA ROSAE | A MUBI Release
filmProgrammings.our_take: The Spanish Civil War profoundly shaped the childhood of legendary director Carlos Saura, whose prolific film career outlived Franco’s brutal dictatorship. This 6-minute musical wonder is a moving child’s-eye look at how conflict warps youth, captured in crumbling, expressive charcoal strokes.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Spencer Tracy and Elizabeth Taylor in Vincente Minnelli's Uproarious Sequel
filmProgrammings.our_take: In Father of the Bride, Spencer Tracy had his work cut out negotiating the comic chaos surrounding his daughter’s impending nuptials. The patter of tiny feet incites a new existential crisis for the curmudgeonly patriarch in this frolicsome sequel, spryly directed by the great Vincente Minnelli.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: The Unusual Subjects: Life on the Farm
filmProgrammings.our_take: Chronicling a year in the life of Vermont farmer Peter Dunning, this determinedly present-tense documentary offers an intimate glimpse into a troubled man’s hermetic existence. Unflinching in its depiction of the ardors of ranch life, Peter and the Farm is a fascinating study in social reclusion.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: A French Masterpiece of Forbidden Love
filmProgrammings.our_take: A film of rocky waters and heady passions, Jean Grémillon’s romantic classic is French cinema at its finest. Aided by Jacques Prévert’s poetic script, Jean Gabin’s bruised masculinity and Michèle Morgan’s melancholic fragility evoke the tragedy of love found at the wrong place and the wrong time.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: An Early Noir from Chinese Filmmaker Diao Yi'nan
filmProgrammings.our_take: Before he made his name with the electric diptych of Black Coal, Thin Ice and The Wild Goose Lake, Diao Yi’nan slunk into the shadowed corners of noir with this bruising locomotive drama. Moodily atmospheric, Night Train embarks on a haunting voyage through the industrial landscapes of modern China.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: An Erotically Charged Melodrama Set Amid Moroccan Ruins
filmProgrammings.our_take: Named after the Berber-Roman remains of a Moroccan town, Volubilis witnesses love endure against wreckage. While present-day corruption echoes across the ancient ruins, an incredible series of amorous gazes shared between the central couple set the screen alight in this enthralling melodrama.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: World Cinema Project Restorations: AFTER THE CURFEW
filmProgrammings.our_take: A full-blooded examination of a postcolonial Indonesia struggling to find its bearings, Usmar Ismail’s classic drama draws from his own past as a freedom fighter. Subsumed by an aching air of disillusionment, the moody cinematography hints at the muddled doubts that linger under a nascent democracy.

primary_film_group.title: Martin Scorsese's World Cinema Project
primary_film_group.description:
“I’m thrilled that these films, restored through The Film Foundation’s World Cinema Project, will be streaming on MUBI. For over three decades, The Film Foundation has worked to preserve, restore, and make available films from every era, genre, and region—over 925 to date. MUBI is an ideal partner for The Film Foundation as they share the same mission: to make films accessible to viewers around the world and to educate about cinema’s artistic, cultural, and historical significance. I look forward to sharing these beautiful restorations with MUBI’s vast and appreciative audience.” —Martin Scorsese, Founder and Chair of the Film Foundation
Martin Scorsese once compared the urgent need for film preservation to a ticking clock. Without optimal means of storage and care, delicate celluloid materials are at the destructive mercy of the elements. Established in 1990, the Film Foundation was set up to rescue fragile film prints that have languished in a state of neglect and deterioration, its principal aim to prevent known gaps in the world’s collective film history from widening into chasms. It’s estimated that for American cinema alone, some 50 percent of pre-1950 films, and 80 percent of movies from the silent era have been lost forever. If these extraordinary statistics apply to an industry with such vast resources as that of America, where does that leave the rest of the world?
The World Cinema Project was launched by the Film Foundation in 2007 with the explicit aim of preserving neglected gems of international cinema. So far, some 47 films from Asia, Africa, Eastern Europe, Central and South America, and the Middle East have been meticulously restored. These films are lightning bolts to the heart of film canons, challenging what we think we know about cultural histories of the medium. Every one of them is a masterwork long out of circulation, at high risk of becoming another statistic without the curative work of the World Cinema Project. We’re thrilled to be partnering with the Film Foundation to bring 19 rare, newly restored classics of international cinema to MUBI over the coming months.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Love, Lust, and Anarchy: The Films of Rainer Werner Fassbinder | THE THIRD GENERATION
filmProgrammings.our_take: Following the shocking events of the “German Autumn,” superstars Eddie Constantine and Bulle Ogier join Fassbinder regular Hanna Schygulla for this ultra stylish yet cynical take on ineffectual middle-class radicalism. A biting political farce that delights in the hysterical chaos of urban disorder.

primary_film_group.title: Love, Lust, and Anarchy:
primary_film_group.description:
Rainer Werner Fassbinder, the eternal enfant terrible of New German Cinema, was a formidable creative force who left behind a colossal body of work before his untimely death at the age of 37. From theater and television to cinema, Fassbinder conquered them all. Imbued with a romantic yet anarchic spirit, his films relish the pleasure and pain of love as well as unrequited longing, all while attesting to the sociopolitical disorder creeping through postwar West Germany. In contrast to the deliberately theatrical staging of his earlier output, our Fassbinder focus centers on the later half of his career, where the director began to inject the stylistic elements of classic melodrama into his provocative character studies.
Such an artistic shift was brought on by his encounter with a retrospective of Douglas Sirk’s filmography in Munich in 1971. Transfixed by the older master’s melodramas, Fassbinder employed his now signature use of primary colors in the art direction and lighting of his subsequent films. Drawn to stories of women trapped by societal hierarchies as well as their own neuroses, Fassbinder often framed his heroines between mirrors, doors, and thresholds, signifying the possibility as well as the futility of escape and self-transformation. The queer poetics of diva worship are also present. As parts of his “BRD Trilogy”—named after the Bundesrepublik Deutschland—films such as Lola (1981) and Veronika Voss (1982) feature cabaret singers and film stars as protagonists, a nod to the silver-screen icons of the past. Blending kitschy glamor with seedy carnal desires, these shocking tableaux of debauchery posit how, in a world where the patriarchy strips women of their autonomy, the path to empowerment lies in the commodification of sexuality. For Fassbinder’s femme fatales, femininity is a kind of performance. In the same vein, his queer masterpiece In a Year of 13 Moons (1978) defies the binary of genders, sensitively portraying a transgender woman’s search for love amid an indifferent and grotesque humanity. Under Fassbinder’s command, irony and catharsis go hand in hand; he even viciously skewered political idealism with his riotous satire The Third Generation (1979). With his band of regular performers and collaborators, Fassbinder formed his own affront to any ideologies of coherence. At a time when the old order is dead and the future proves hopeless, Fassbinder’s cinema sets the ground on fire, building a new world out of its ashes.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: A Window into New Indian Cinema: Rahul Jain's INVISIBLE DEMONS
filmProgrammings.our_take: An urgent look at the climate crisis, Rahul Jain’s eye-opening essay unfolds in a series of stunning, often birds-eye images of a very man-made disaster. Hard to look away from and impossible to ignore, Invisible Demons immerses us in climate chaos as we hear from those caught in the crossfire.

primary_film_group.title: A Window into New Indian Cinema
primary_film_group.title_upcase: A WINDOW INTO NEW INDIAN CINEMA
primary_film_group.description: Contemporary independent Indian cinema is, like the country itself, an eclectic symphony of voices. This program looks at India through the eyes of some of its boldest emerging indie filmmakers. By bringing the local to global audiences, these works foreground their directors’ nonconformist perspectives and showcase diverse stories of life at the margins of India’s towns and cities. Whether tracking the rapidly changing social or political situation of its cities and towns, or documenting its rich tapestries of folk customs, social histories and traditions, these films open a window on a country that’s always on the cusp of change. Prepare to be inspired.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Adèle Haenel in a Sparkling, Screwball Comedy
filmProgrammings.our_take: Already one of the finest actors of her generation, Adèle Haenel (Portrait of a Lady on Fire) proves herself an effervescent comedic force in this part-satirical, part-screwball policier farce from Pierre Salvadori. Co-starring the star of Salvadori’s Priceless, Audrey Tautou!

filmProgrammings.email_subject: One of the Greatest Documentaries of All Time
filmProgrammings.our_take: Dziga Vertov’s masterpiece remains a visually thrilling chronicle of modern life, and an ode to the power of film. A lucid mixture of documentary and avant-garde techniques, it’s a radical redefinition of cinema’s boundaries—essential viewing that is just as groundbreaking many years later.

296.short_synopsis: Twenty-four hours in the life of the inhabitants of a large city. From dawn to dusk, his device perched on his tripod, the man with a movie camera records and captures the hustle and bustle of an ordinary day.

318.title: Night of the Living Dead

content_rating.label: adult
content_rating.description: Contains adult material and themes. Suitable only for adults.

318.short_synopsis: A disparate group of individuals takes refuge in an abandoned house when corpses begin to leave the graveyard in search of fresh human bodies to devour. The pragmatic Ben does his best to control the situation, but when the murderous zombies surround the house, the other survivors begin to panic.
318.short_synopsis_html: A disparate group of individuals takes refuge in an abandoned house when corpses begin to leave the graveyard in search of fresh human bodies to devour. The pragmatic Ben does his best to control the situation, but when the murderous zombies surround the house, the other survivors begin to panic.
318.default_editorial: Some like ghost stories, and some prefer their undead as a bloodthirsty horde. Here’s where the world’s zombie obsession began: George Romero’s landmark classic, a raging, subversive, apocalyptic bonfire of a film. By the time the lights came up, horror would never be the same—and it still shocks.

748.title: The Tales of Hoffmann

content_rating.label: general
content_rating.description: Generally suitable for all ages, but viewer discretion is advised.

748.short_synopsis: A melancholy poet reflects on three women he loved and lost in the past—a mechanical performing doll, a seductive Venetian courtesan, and a soprano who sings herself to death—all of whom broke his heart in different ways.
748.short_synopsis_html: A melancholy poet reflects on three women he loved and lost in the past—a mechanical performing doll, a seductive Venetian courtesan, and a soprano who sings herself to death—all of whom broke his heart in different ways.
748.default_editorial: Powell & Pressburger’s resplendent Technicolor adaptation of the E.T.A. Hoffmann opera reveals, once more, the duo’s boundless cinematic imagination. Unabashedly opulent in its flamboyant colour-coded scenes, which daringly combine theatre, dance, opera and film, it’s a total feast for the senses.

2158.title: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room
2158.original_title: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room
2158.title_upcase: ENRON: THE SMARTEST GUYS IN THE ROOM

content_rating.label: adult
content_rating.description: Contains adult material and themes. Suitable only for adults.

2158.short_synopsis: The inside story of one of history’s biggest business scandals, in which top executives of America’s 7th largest company walked away with over one billion dollars while investors and employees lost everything. A story of corporate greed and CEO hubris which foreshadowed the current financial crises.
2158.short_synopsis_html: The inside story of one of history’s biggest business scandals, in which top executives of America’s 7th largest company walked away with over one billion dollars while investors and employees lost everything. A story of corporate greed and CEO hubris which foreshadowed the current financial crises.
2158.default_editorial: It’s fascinating to watch Alex Gibney’s searing investigation of Enron’s corporate malfeasance in the years following the 2008 economic crash. What once looked like a historic reckoning, now feels terrifyingly prophetic. Methodical and damning, it’s one of the great documentarian’s very best films.

What once looked like a historic reckoning, now feels terrifyingly prophetic. Methodical and damning, it’s one of the great documentarian’s very best films.

2416.title: Paris Belongs to Us

content_rating.label: caution
content_rating.description: Contains material that may not be suitable for children or young adults.

2416.short_synopsis: Young literature student, Anne, immerses herself in a theater troupe of bohemians and becomes involved with the producer Gerard, who is staging Shakespeare’s Pericles. But it’s not long before her life falls under the shadow of a devious and powerful—though perhaps nonexistent?—conspiracy.
2416.short_synopsis_html: Young literature student, Anne, immerses herself in a theater troupe of bohemians and becomes involved with the producer Gerard, who is staging Shakespeare’s Pericles. But it’s not long before her life falls under the shadow of a devious and powerful—though perhaps nonexistent?—conspiracy.
2416.default_editorial: One of the key inciting films of the French New Wave, Jacques Rivette’s rough-and-ready debut is an enigmatic time-capsule of Left Bank Paris. Centering on a no-budget theatrical production and imbued with conspiratorial anxiety, this quasi-thriller couldn’t be mistaken for the work of anyone else!

2783.title: Night Train

content_rating.label: adult
content_rating.description: Contains adult material and themes. Suitable only for adults.

2783.short_synopsis: Wu Hongyan is a female bailiff in a regional court in West China dealing with women awaiting execution—more often than not, sentenced for crimes of passion. Every weekend, without much luck, she looks for love at the Good Luck Matchmaking dance, until she meets the husband of one of her prisoners.

Every weekend, without much luck, she looks for love at the Good Luck Matchmaking dance, until she meets the husband of one of her prisoners.
2783.default_editorial: Before he made his name with the electric diptych of Black Coal, Thin Ice and The Wild Goose Lake, Diao Yi’nan slunk into the shadowed corners of noir with this bruising locomotive drama. Moodily atmospheric, Night Train embarks on a haunting voyage through the industrial landscapes of modern China.

content_rating.label: adult
content_rating.description: Contains adult material and themes. Suitable only for adults.

12075.short_synopsis: Winter 1978/79 in West Berlin. A group of inept middle-class German radicals—united less by their political convictions than their secretive behavior—goes underground after the killer Paul is shot by the police. The young terrorists kidnap Peter Lurz, the representative of a US computer firm.

22383.title: La ricotta

content_rating.label: caution
content_rating.description: Contains material that may not be suitable for children or young adults.

22383.short_synopsis: Pier Paolo Pasolini’s contribution to the omnibus film Ro.Go.Pa.G. casts Orson Welles as a director attempting to make a film of the crucifixion of Jesus—all while he, the cast, and crew behave in the most un-Christlike ways imaginable.
22383.short_synopsis_html: Pier Paolo Pasolini’s contribution to the omnibus film Ro.Go.Pa.G. casts Orson Welles as a director attempting to make a film of the crucifixion of Jesus—all while he, the cast, and crew behave in the most un-Christlike ways imaginable.
22383.default_editorial: Playing havoc with the hierarchies of both religion and filmmaking, Pier Paolo Pasolini’s riotous farce ferociously articulates his radical beliefs, for which he was charged with blasphemy. Bolstered by Orson Welles’s magnetic presence, the film ingeniously mixes zany slapstick with gutting tragedy.
22383.default_editorial_html: Playing havoc with the hierarchies of both religion and filmmaking, Pier Paolo Pasolini’s riotous farce ferociously articulates his radical beliefs, for which he was charged with blasphemy. 27804.title: The White Reindeer

content_rating.label: caution
content_rating.description: Contains material that may not be suitable for children or young adults.

27804.short_synopsis: A newly-married woman becomes frustrated as her husband, a reindeer herder for an Arctic village, spends much of his time away. Desperate for affection, she visits a shaman who offers a potion that makes her irresistibly desirable, but at a terrible cost: she becomes a bloodthirsty shapeshifter.
27804.short_synopsis_html: A newly-married woman becomes frustrated as her husband, a reindeer herder for an Arctic village, spends much of his time away. Desperate for affection, she visits a shaman who offers a potion that makes her irresistibly desirable, but at a terrible cost: she becomes a bloodthirsty shapeshifter.
27804.default_editorial: Drawing from the deep well of beliefs of the semi-nomadic Sámi people, Erik Blomberg’s Finnish folk horror is a snow-encrusted tale of shape-shifting shamanism. Weirdness lurks deep in the desolate landscape of Lapland, where the fight to survive rubs up against the insatiable hunger for love.

28170.title: Remorques

content_rating.label: caution
content_rating.description: Contains material that may not be suitable for children or young adults.

28170.short_synopsis: For André and the other crew members of the Cyclone, existence is divided between the stormy seas and the safety of life at home with their wives. When André meets temptation in the form of the alluring Catherine during a risky rescue, he comes perilously close to betraying his wife of 10 years.
28170.short_synopsis_html: For André and the other crew members of the Cyclone, existence is divided between the stormy seas and the safety of life at home with their wives. When André meets temptation in the form of the alluring Catherine during a risky rescue, he comes perilously close to betraying his wife of 10 years.
28170.default_editorial: A film of rocky waters and heady passions, Jean Grémillon’s romantic classic is French cinema at its finest. Aided by Jacques Prévert’s poetic script, Jean Gabin’s bruised masculinity and Michèle Morgan’s melancholic fragility evoke the tragedy of love found at the wrong place and the wrong time.

29795.title: Faces of Children

content_rating.label: general
content_rating.description: Generally suitable for all ages, but viewer discretion is advised.

29795.short_synopsis: A man whose wife has died remarries, and his new wife has a daughter of her own from a previous marriage. The man’s young son, however, who loved his mother deeply and misses her terribly, resents his father’s new wife, not wanting her to take the place of his beloved mother.
29795.short_synopsis_html: A man whose wife has died remarries, and his new wife has a daughter of her own from a previous marriage. The man’s young son, however, who loved his mother deeply and misses her terribly, resents his father’s new wife, not wanting her to take the place of his beloved mother.
29795.default_editorial: An unsentimental portrait of childhood blues, this tumultuous family drama from French master Jacques Feyder is remarkably modern for its time. Awe-striking in their resplendence, the mountains and rivers of Switzerland beautifully mirror the stormy emotions that swell within a motherless young boy.

38933.title: Father's Little Dividend

content_rating.label: general
content_rating.description: Generally suitable for all ages, but viewer discretion is advised.

38933.short_synopsis: In this sequel to Father of the Bride, Stanley Banks and his wife Ellie find their daughter Kay is now pregnant. Not ready to be a grandfather, Stanley keeps quiet while everyone else fawns over the mother-to-be. Ironically, his silence makes him the person Kay turns to the most for help.
38933.short_synopsis_html: In this sequel to Father of the Bride, Stanley Banks and his wife Ellie find their daughter Kay is now pregnant. Not ready to be a grandfather, Stanley keeps quiet while everyone else fawns over the mother-to-be. Ironically, his silence makes him the person Kay turns to the most for help.
38933.default_editorial: In Father of the Bride, Spencer Tracy had his work cut out negotiating the comic chaos surrounding his daughter’s impending nuptials. 157584.title: Peter and the Farm

content_rating.description: Contains adult material and themes. Suitable only for adults.

178453.short_synopsis: From the segregated American South to the fashion capitals of the world, operatic fashion editor André Leon Talley’s life and career are on full display, in a poignant portrait that includes appearances by Anna Wintour, Marc Jacobs, Tom Ford, Bethann Hardison, Valentino, and Manolo Blahnik.
178453.short_synopsis_html: From the segregated American South to the fashion capitals of the world, operatic fashion editor André Leon Talley’s life and career are on full display, in a poignant portrait that includes appearances by Anna Wintour, Marc Jacobs, Tom Ford, Bethann Hardison, Valentino, and Manolo Blahnik.

203215.title: Sorry Angel

content_rating.label: adult
content_rating.description: Contains adult material and themes. Suitable only for adults.

203215.short_synopsis: Jacques is a writer living in Paris. He hasn’t turned 40 but already mistrusts that the best in life is yet to come. Arthur is a student living in Brittany. He reads and smiles a lot and refuses to think that everything in life might not be possible. Jacques and Arthur will like each other.
203215.short_synopsis_html: Jacques is a writer living in Paris. He hasn’t turned 40 but already mistrusts that the best in life is yet to come. Arthur is a student living in Brittany. 203215.default_editorial: A film of profound resilience and fragility, Christophe Honoré’s queer romantic drama glows with the warmth of a new love that blooms underneath the specter of the AIDS crisis. 203900.title: The Trouble with You

content_rating.description: Contains adult material and themes. Suitable only for adults.

203900.short_synopsis: Police detective Yvonne, the widow of police chief Santi, a local hero, discovers that her husband was in fact a crooked cop. Determined to right all the wrongs he committed, she meets with Antoine, who was unjustly imprisoned by Santi for 8 years, leading to a troublesome sequence of wild mishaps.
203900.short_synopsis_html: Police detective Yvonne, the widow of police chief Santi, a local hero, discovers that her husband was in fact a crooked cop. 206136.title: Hayati (My Life)

content_rating.label: caution
content_rating.description: Contains material that may not be suitable for children or young adults.

206136.short_synopsis: In 2015, Ossamah and his son were tripped up by a TV reporter. The moment was filmed and soon became a symbolic image of the Syrian conflict. While the incident helped Ossamah get his dream job in Madrid, the rest of his family remain stuck in Turkey as their chances of obtaining a visa are fading.
206136.short_synopsis_html: In 2015, Ossamah and his son were tripped up by a TV reporter. The moment was filmed and soon became a symbolic image of the Syrian conflict. 206136.default_editorial: A symbol in the media for the hostility endured by asylum seekers, Ossamah Al Mohsen continues to face bureaucratic cruelty after settling in Spain. Bringing together his new life and the fate of Syrian footballers stuck in Turkey, this tender documentary lends a human depth to faceless statistics.

211720.title: The River

content_rating.label: caution
content_rating.description: Contains material that may not be suitable for children or young adults.

211720.short_synopsis: On a vast plain in Kazakhstan, surrounded by mountaintops, Aslan and his four younger brothers are put to work continuously by their strict father. They live secluded lives, with no time for pleasure, until the boys’ accidental discovery of the modern world threatens their way of life.
211720.short_synopsis_html: On a vast plain in Kazakhstan, surrounded by mountaintops, Aslan and his four younger brothers are put to work continuously by their strict father. 211720.default_editorial: Reminiscent of Yorgos Lanthimos’s Dogtooth, Emir Baigazin’s unsettling drama dreams up an eerily sequestered existence in a remote Kazakh village where paternal authoritarianism reigns. Under the intrusion of technology, the lush, ascetic cinematography gives way to shocking familial transgressions.

219785.short_synopsis: After an Air Force jet crashes in the Himalayas, an old shepherd leaves his herd to find its pilot. But the mountain where the jet fell is sacred and the shepherd’s intentions are not.
219785.short_synopsis_html: After an Air Force jet crashes in the Himalayas, an old shepherd leaves his herd to find its pilot. But the mountain where the jet fell is sacred and the shepherd’s intentions are not.

285524.title: Earwig

content_rating.label: adult
content_rating.description: Contains adult material and themes. Suitable only for adults.

285524.short_synopsis: Albert is employed to look after Mia, a girl with teeth of ice. Mia never leaves the apartment, where the shutters are always closed. The Master rings regularly to enquire after Mia’s wellbeing until the day Albert is instructed that he must prepare the child to leave.
285524.short_synopsis_html: Albert is employed to look after Mia, a girl with teeth of ice. Mia never leaves the apartment, where the shutters are always closed. The Master rings regularly to enquire after Mia’s wellbeing until the day Albert is instructed that he must prepare the child to leave.
285524.default_editorial: Strange objects, secret prisons, and uncanny stories of children growing up continue to fascinate Lucile Hadžihalilović in the eerie and mysterious Earwig. 288531.title: Surviving You, Always

content_rating.label: caution
content_rating.description: Contains material that may not be suitable for children or young adults.

288531.short_synopsis: A voice-over by psychologist Timothy Leary professes that psychedelic drugs expand the consciousness. Meanwhile, subtitles tell us of a teenager in 90s London who spends acid-infused weekends with a friend. Just like hallucinations, teenage friendships feel like they’ll last forever—but rarely do.
288531.short_synopsis_html: A voice-over by psychologist Timothy Leary professes that psychedelic drugs expand the consciousness. Meanwhile, subtitles tell us of a teenager in 90s London who spends acid-infused weekends with a friend. Just like hallucinations, teenage friendships feel like they’ll last forever—but rarely do.
288531.default_editorial: While an icon of 1960s counterculture enthuses mystically about hallucinogens, Morgan Quaintance reflects on growing up high with sober disillusionment. In monochrome recollections of ’90s South London, the British artist is romantic about only one thing: in the end, love is the drug that remains.

311403.title: Invisible Demons

content_rating.label: caution
content_rating.description: Contains material that may not be suitable for children or young adults.

311403.short_synopsis: In the sprawling mega city of Delhi, the dangers of climate change are present, not future, for 30 million inhabitants fighting to survive. Invisible Demons explores the dramatic consequences of India’s growing economy, capturing a city in crisis, and our collective climate realities.
311403.short_synopsis_html: In the sprawling mega city of Delhi, the dangers of climate change are present, not future, for 30 million inhabitants fighting to survive. Invisible Demons explores the dramatic consequences of India’s growing economy, capturing a city in crisis, and our collective climate realities.
311403.default_editorial: An urgent look at the climate crisis, Rahul Jain’s eye-opening essay unfolds in a series of stunning, often birds-eye images of a very man-made disaster. Hard to look away from and impossible to ignore, Invisible Demons immerses us in climate chaos as we hear from those caught in the crossfire.

content_rating.label: caution
content_rating.description: Contains material that may not be suitable for children or young adults.

313966.short_synopsis: Saura creates and recovers more than thirty images, drawings and photos that he prints, manipulates, plays with and then films, to create a story that recreates the Spanish civil war, but also reflects the horrors of a universal war, from the eyes of a child and its environment.
313966.short_synopsis_html: Saura creates and recovers more than thirty images, drawings and photos that he prints, manipulates, plays with and then films, to create a story that recreates the Spanish civil war, but also reflects the horrors of a universal war, from the eyes of a child and its environment.
313966.default_editorial: The Spanish Civil War profoundly shaped the childhood of legendary director Carlos Saura, whose prolific film career outlived Franco’s brutal dictatorship. This 6-minute musical wonder is a moving child’s-eye look at how conflict warps youth, captured in crumbling, expressive charcoal strokes.

316211.title: A Human Certainty

content_rating.label: general
content_rating.description: Generally suitable for all ages, but viewer discretion is advised.

316211.short_synopsis: A Human Certainty follows the neurotic ramblings of a death-obsessed romantic in the throes of post-breakup blues. The street photographer Weegee, Saint Lidwina, and the filmmaker’s own spiritualist grandmother all come together to reflect on a particularly painful day at the beach.

316211.default_editorial: In A Human Certainty, the brooding, post-breakup narrator senses an ending wherever his thoughts take him—even a beach may as well be a graveyard. 316795.title: Spectre: Sanity, Madness & The Family

content_rating.label: caution
content_rating.description: Contains material that may not be suitable for children or young adults.

316795.short_synopsis: Jean, the youngest of a large family, grew up in a community influenced by Chris, a spiritual guide. After receiving a tape from his sister, he rediscovers voices and sounds from his past. As the memories begin to emerge, he decides to follow in Chris’ footsteps, only to discover his family secret.
316795.short_synopsis_html: Jean, the youngest of a large family, grew up in a community influenced by Chris, a spiritual guide. After receiving a tape from his sister, he rediscovers voices and sounds from his past. As the memories begin to emerge, he decides to follow in Chris’ footsteps, only to discover his family secret.
316795.default_editorial: Excavating an unusual family archive laden with secrets, this mesmerizing first feature from French composer Jean-Baptiste de Laubier, aka Para One, is a sonic journey through the ghosts of childhood. Echoing his collaborations with Céline Sciamma, the enigmatic score unlocks a portal to the past.

333277.title: The African Desperate

content_rating.label: adult
content_rating.description: Contains adult material and themes. Suitable only for adults.

333277.short_synopsis: It’s MFA grad Palace Bryant’s final 24 hours in art school, and she is not going to the fucking graduation party! She needs to get back home to Chicago from Upstate New York, but that means surviving a hazy, hilarious, and hallucinatory odyssey, stumbling from academic critiques to backseat hookups.
333277.short_synopsis_html: It’s MFA grad Palace Bryant’s final 24 hours in art school, and she is not going to the fucking graduation party! In monochrome recollections of ’90s South London, the British artist is romantic about only one thing: in the end, love is the drug that remains.

primary_film_group.title: Thinking of You:
primary_film_group.description: It’s 3am again, and Morgan Quaintance is awake. In 1993, this was the time for watching fireworks and falling in love. Now it is the hour of insomnia, solitude, and thinking about “odd things”—like the possible saintliness of his suffering. Often set at night and in the cloudy waters of post-breakup sadness, both films in our double bill find the British artist-filmmaker immersed in introspection. In Surviving You, Always (2020) and A Human Certainty (2021), Quaintance is intermittently carried away from himself and his London surrounds by digressive streams of thought: reflecting on his family history across the Black Atlantic in one moment, then anti-psychiatry of the 1960s and photojournalism of the 1930s in the next. In the two shorts, he also beautifully captures the poor image that is memory: the people of the past are glimpsed in close-up and slow, staccato motion, with the image out of focus and further obscured by grainy, monochrome 16mm film. Quaintance supplements that uncertain image in various ways, continually combining written word, sound, music and image to create formally generous films. Writing as a critic for the magazine Art Monthly, Quaintance has recently decried the slide of British multiculturalism into a monoculture: everything looks the same, he laments, and says the same thing. Nothing could be further from the truth when it comes to these two shorts. Intensely intimate, tender and wry, his idiosyncratic films escape this contemporary condition.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Thinking of You: Two Films by Morgan Quaintance | A HUMAN CERTAINTY
filmProgrammings.our_take: In A Human Certainty, the brooding, post-breakup narrator senses an ending wherever his thoughts take him—even a beach may as well be a graveyard. Balancing wounding honesty with wry humor, Morgan Quaintance captures the inescapable torment of heartbreak, where all is haunted and everything hurts.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Alex Gibney's Searing Investigation of Corporate Malfeasance
filmProgrammings.our_take: It’s fascinating to watch Alex Gibney’s searing investigation of Enron’s corporate malfeasance in the years following the 2008 economic crash. What once looked like a historic reckoning, now feels terrifyingly prophetic. Methodical and damning, it’s one of the great documentarian’s very best films.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Christophe Honoré's Heady Tale of Love and Resilience
filmProgrammings.our_take: A film of profound resilience and fragility, Christophe Honoré’s queer romantic drama glows with the warmth of a new love that blooms underneath the specter of the AIDS crisis. Intimacy is evoked, not only with electrifying carnal touches, but also through thrilling exchanges on art and literature.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Martine Syms's THE AFRICAN DESPERATE | A MUBI Release
filmProgrammings.our_take: Chaos reigns in the riotously funny debut feature from visual artist Martine Syms. With a breakthrough performance from Diamond Stingily, this hallucinatory day-in-the-life of a Black artist is a rollicking satire of art-world pretensions and a rowdy portrayal of sex and drugs in the Internet age.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: A Sequestered Family Gone Haywire
filmProgrammings.our_take: Reminiscent of Yorgos Lanthimos’s Dogtooth, Emir Baigazin’s unsettling drama dreams up an eerily sequestered existence in a remote Kazakh village where paternal authoritarianism reigns. Under the intrusion of technology, the lush, ascetic cinematography gives way to shocking familial transgressions.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Erik Blomberg's THE WHITE REINDEER | A MUBI Release
filmProgrammings.our_take: Drawing from the deep well of beliefs of the semi-nomadic Sámi people, Erik Blomberg’s Finnish folk horror is a snow-encrusted tale of shape-shifting shamanism. Weirdness lurks deep in the desolate landscape of Lapland, where the fight to survive rubs up against the insatiable hunger for love.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: A Window into New Indian Cinema: THE GOLD-LADEN SHEEP & THE SACRED MOUNTAIN
filmProgrammings.our_take: In this mystical drama, a shepherd’s holy-mountain quest transforms into a metaphysical fable about mankind’s search for the sacred. The first film spoken in the Gaddi dialect of a nomadic Himalayan tribe, Ridham Janve’s bold debut ingeniously segues between the surreal and the documentary.

primary_film_group.title: A Window into New Indian Cinema
primary_film_group.title_upcase: A WINDOW INTO NEW INDIAN CINEMA
primary_film_group.description: Contemporary independent Indian cinema is, like the country itself, an eclectic symphony of voices. This program looks at India through the eyes of some of its boldest emerging indie filmmakers. By bringing the local to global audiences, these works foreground their directors’ nonconformist perspectives and showcase diverse stories of life at the margins of India’s towns and cities. Whether tracking the rapidly changing social or political situation of its cities and towns, or documenting its rich tapestries of folk customs, social histories and traditions, these films open a window on a country that’s always on the cusp of change. Prepare to be inspired.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Paris Belongs to Jacques Rivette!
filmProgrammings.our_take: One of the key inciting films of the French New Wave, Jacques Rivette’s rough-and-ready debut is an enigmatic time-capsule of Left Bank Paris. Centering on a no-budget theatrical production and imbued with conspiratorial anxiety, this quasi-thriller couldn’t be mistaken for the work of anyone else!

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Powell & Pressburger Together & Apart: THE TALES OF HOFFMANN
filmProgrammings.our_take: Powell & Pressburger’s resplendent Technicolor adaptation of the E.T.A. Hoffmann opera reveals, once more, the duo’s boundless cinematic imagination. Unabashedly opulent in its flamboyant colour-coded scenes, which daringly combine theatre, dance, opera and film, it’s a total feast for the senses.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Lucile Hadžihalilović's EARWIG | A MUBI Release
filmProgrammings.our_take: Strange objects, secret prisons, and uncanny stories of children growing up continue to fascinate Lucile Hadžihalilović in the eerie and mysterious Earwig. Spine-tingling in both its beauty and its creepiness, her cinema of curiosities shares a surrealist realm with Cronenberg and Lynch.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: The Passions of Pasolini: LA RICOTTA
filmProgrammings.our_take: Playing havoc with the hierarchies of both religion and filmmaking, Pier Paolo Pasolini’s riotous farce ferociously articulates his radical beliefs, for which he was charged with blasphemy. Bolstered by Orson Welles’s magnetic presence, the film ingeniously mixes zany slapstick with gutting tragedy.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Refugee Lives Told in Vivid Depth
filmProgrammings.our_take: A symbol in the media for the hostility endured by asylum seekers, Ossamah Al Mohsen continues to face bureaucratic cruelty after settling in Spain. Bringing together his new life and the fate of Syrian footballers stuck in Turkey, this tender documentary lends a human depth to faceless statistics.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Carlos Saura's ROSA ROSAE | A MUBI Release
filmProgrammings.our_take: The Spanish Civil War profoundly shaped the childhood of legendary director Carlos Saura, whose prolific film career outlived Franco’s brutal dictatorship. This 6-minute musical wonder is a moving child’s-eye look at how conflict warps youth, captured in crumbling, expressive charcoal strokes.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Spencer Tracy and Elizabeth Taylor in Vincente Minnelli's Uproarious Sequel
filmProgrammings.our_take: In Father of the Bride, Spencer Tracy had his work cut out negotiating the comic chaos surrounding his daughter’s impending nuptials. The patter of tiny feet incites a new existential crisis for the curmudgeonly patriarch in this frolicsome sequel, spryly directed by the great Vincente Minnelli.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: The Unusual Subjects: Life on the Farm
filmProgrammings.our_take: Chronicling a year in the life of Vermont farmer Peter Dunning, this determinedly present-tense documentary offers an intimate glimpse into a troubled man’s hermetic existence. Unflinching in its depiction of the ardors of ranch life, Peter and the Farm is a fascinating study in social reclusion.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: A French Masterpiece of Forbidden Love
filmProgrammings.our_take: A film of rocky waters and heady passions, Jean Grémillon’s romantic classic is French cinema at its finest. Aided by Jacques Prévert’s poetic script, Jean Gabin’s bruised masculinity and Michèle Morgan’s melancholic fragility evoke the tragedy of love found at the wrong place and the wrong time.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: An Early Noir from Chinese Filmmaker Diao Yi'nan
filmProgrammings.our_take: Before he made his name with the electric diptych of Black Coal, Thin Ice and The Wild Goose Lake, Diao Yi’nan slunk into the shadowed corners of noir with this bruising locomotive drama. Moodily atmospheric, Night Train embarks on a haunting voyage through the industrial landscapes of modern China.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: An Erotically Charged Melodrama Set Amid Moroccan Ruins
filmProgrammings.our_take: Named after the Berber-Roman remains of a Moroccan town, Volubilis witnesses love endure against wreckage. While present-day corruption echoes across the ancient ruins, an incredible series of amorous gazes shared between the central couple set the screen alight in this enthralling melodrama.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: World Cinema Project Restorations: AFTER THE CURFEW
filmProgrammings.our_take: A full-blooded examination of a postcolonial Indonesia struggling to find its bearings, Usmar Ismail’s classic drama draws from his own past as a freedom fighter. Subsumed by an aching air of disillusionment, the moody cinematography hints at the muddled doubts that linger under a nascent democracy.

primary_film_group.title: Martin Scorsese's World Cinema Project
primary_film_group.description:
“I’m thrilled that these films, restored through The Film Foundation’s World Cinema Project, will be streaming on MUBI. For over three decades, The Film Foundation has worked to preserve, restore, and make available films from every era, genre, and region—over 925 to date. MUBI is an ideal partner for The Film Foundation as they share the same mission: to make films accessible to viewers around the world and to educate about cinema’s artistic, cultural, and historical significance. I look forward to sharing these beautiful restorations with MUBI’s vast and appreciative audience.” —Martin Scorsese, Founder and Chair of the Film Foundation
Martin Scorsese once compared the urgent need for film preservation to a ticking clock. Without optimal means of storage and care, delicate celluloid materials are at the destructive mercy of the elements. Established in 1990, the Film Foundation was set up to rescue fragile film prints that have languished in a state of neglect and deterioration, its principal aim to prevent known gaps in the world’s collective film history from widening into chasms. It’s estimated that for American cinema alone, some 50 percent of pre-1950 films, and 80 percent of movies from the silent era have been lost forever. If these extraordinary statistics apply to an industry with such vast resources as that of America, where does that leave the rest of the world?
The World Cinema Project was launched by the Film Foundation in 2007 with the explicit aim of preserving neglected gems of international cinema. So far, some 47 films from Asia, Africa, Eastern Europe, Central and South America, and the Middle East have been meticulously restored. These films are lightning bolts to the heart of film canons, challenging what we think we know about cultural histories of the medium. Every one of them is a masterwork long out of circulation, at high risk of becoming another statistic without the curative work of the World Cinema Project. We’re thrilled to be partnering with the Film Foundation to bring 19 rare, newly restored classics of international cinema to MUBI over the coming months.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Love, Lust, and Anarchy: The Films of Rainer Werner Fassbinder | THE THIRD GENERATION
filmProgrammings.our_take: Following the shocking events of the “German Autumn,” superstars Eddie Constantine and Bulle Ogier join Fassbinder regular Hanna Schygulla for this ultra stylish yet cynical take on ineffectual middle-class radicalism. A biting political farce that delights in the hysterical chaos of urban disorder.

primary_film_group.title: Love, Lust, and Anarchy:
primary_film_group.description:
Rainer Werner Fassbinder, the eternal enfant terrible of New German Cinema, was a formidable creative force who left behind a colossal body of work before his untimely death at the age of 37. From theater and television to cinema, Fassbinder conquered them all. Imbued with a romantic yet anarchic spirit, his films relish the pleasure and pain of love as well as unrequited longing, all while attesting to the sociopolitical disorder creeping through postwar West Germany. In contrast to the deliberately theatrical staging of his earlier output, our Fassbinder focus centers on the later half of his career, where the director began to inject the stylistic elements of classic melodrama into his provocative character studies.
Such an artistic shift was brought on by his encounter with a retrospective of Douglas Sirk’s filmography in Munich in 1971. Transfixed by the older master’s melodramas, Fassbinder employed his now signature use of primary colors in the art direction and lighting of his subsequent films. Drawn to stories of women trapped by societal hierarchies as well as their own neuroses, Fassbinder often framed his heroines between mirrors, doors, and thresholds, signifying the possibility as well as the futility of escape and self-transformation. The queer poetics of diva worship are also present. As parts of his “BRD Trilogy”—named after the Bundesrepublik Deutschland—films such as Lola (1981) and Veronika Voss (1982) feature cabaret singers and film stars as protagonists, a nod to the silver-screen icons of the past. Blending kitschy glamor with seedy carnal desires, these shocking tableaux of debauchery posit how, in a world where the patriarchy strips women of their autonomy, the path to empowerment lies in the commodification of sexuality. For Fassbinder’s femme fatales, femininity is a kind of performance. In the same vein, his queer masterpiece In a Year of 13 Moons (1978) defies the binary of genders, sensitively portraying a transgender woman’s search for love amid an indifferent and grotesque humanity. Under Fassbinder’s command, irony and catharsis go hand in hand; he even viciously skewered political idealism with his riotous satire The Third Generation (1979). With his band of regular performers and collaborators, Fassbinder formed his own affront to any ideologies of coherence. At a time when the old order is dead and the future proves hopeless, Fassbinder’s cinema sets the ground on fire, building a new world out of its ashes.

Rainer Werner Fassbinder, the eternal enfant terrible of New German Cinema, was a formidable creative force who left behind a colossal body of work before his untimely death at the age of 37. filmProgrammings.email_subject: A Window into New Indian Cinema: Rahul Jain's INVISIBLE DEMONS
filmProgrammings.our_take: An urgent look at the climate crisis, Rahul Jain’s eye-opening essay unfolds in a series of stunning, often birds-eye images of a very man-made disaster. Hard to look away from and impossible to ignore, Invisible Demons immerses us in climate chaos as we hear from those caught in the crossfire.

Hard to look away from and impossible to ignore, Invisible Demons immerses us in climate chaos as we hear from those caught in the crossfire.

primary_film_group.title: A Window into New Indian Cinema
primary_film_group.title_upcase: A WINDOW INTO NEW INDIAN CINEMA
primary_film_group.description: Contemporary independent Indian cinema is, like the country itself, an eclectic symphony of voices. This program looks at India through the eyes of some of its boldest emerging indie filmmakers. By bringing the local to global audiences, these works foreground their directors’ nonconformist perspectives and showcase diverse stories of life at the margins of India’s towns and cities. Whether tracking the rapidly changing social or political situation of its cities and towns, or documenting its rich tapestries of folk customs, social histories and traditions, these films open a window on a country that’s always on the cusp of change. Prepare to be inspired.

filmProgrammings.email_subject: Adèle Haenel in a Sparkling, Screwball Comedy
filmProgrammings.our_take: Already one of the finest actors of her generation, Adèle Haenel (Portrait of a Lady on Fire) proves herself an effervescent comedic force in this part-satirical, part-screwball policier farce from Pierre Salvadori. Co-starring the star of Salvadori’s Priceless, Audrey Tautou!

Co-starring the star of Salvadori’s Priceless, Audrey Tautou!

filmProgrammings.email_subject: One of the Greatest Documentaries of All Time
filmProgrammings.our_take: Dziga Vertov’s masterpiece remains a visually thrilling chronicle of modern life, and an ode to the power of film. A lucid mixture of documentary and avant-garde techniques, it’s a radical redefinition of cinema’s boundaries—essential viewing that is just as groundbreaking many years later.
